tit.e: Totsuka no Tsurugi (a sword in the Japanese Myth)
Totsuka no Tsurugi (a sword in the Japanese Myth)

sen.j: 十束剣（とつかのつるぎ）は日本神話に登場する剣。
sen.e: Totsuka no tsurugi is a sword which appears in the Japanese myth.

sen.j: 「十握剣」「十拳剣」「十掬剣」など様々に表記される。
sen.e: It is written in various ways such as '十握剣,' '十拳剣,' '十掬剣,' and so on.

sen.j: 様々な場面で登場していることや、「10束（束は長さの単位で、拳1つ分の幅）の長さの剣」という意味の名前であることから、一つの剣の固有の名称ではなく、長剣の一般名詞と考えられ、それぞれ別の剣であるとされる。
sen.e: It is not a proper name for a particular sword, but a general noun for the long swords because they appear in many scenes and the name means 'a long sword with 10 tsuka long (a unit of length, one tsuka is equal to the length of a fist),' therefore they are considered different swords.

It is thought to be a general noun for a long sword rather than a proper name for a particular sword, since the term is found in various situations and it literally refers to 'a sword with 10 tsuka long' (tsuka is a unit of length; one tsuka is equal to the length of a fist), therefore the Totsuka no Tsurugi in several myths are considered different from each other.

sen.j: 最初に登場するのは神産みにおいてイザナギがカグツチを斬る場面である。

sen.e: This sword was called Ame no Ohabari or Itsu no Ohabari (the name of Itsu no Ohabari was later used as a name of Takemikazuchi's father god).

sen.j: アマテラスとスサノオの誓約の場面では、古事記ではスサノオが持っていた十拳剣からアマテラスが3柱の女神を産んでいる。
sen.e: According to Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), when Amaterasu and Susanoo made an oath, she gave birth to three goddesses from totsuka no tsurugi which Susanoo had.

sen.j: 最も有名なのはヤマタノオロチ退治の時にスサノオが使った十拳剣（別名「天羽々斬（あめのはばきり）」。"羽々"とは"大蛇"の意味）。
sen.e: The most famous totsuka no tsurugi is the one that Susanoo used when he killed off yamata no orochi (eight-forked-snake).

sen.e: The most famous Totsuka no Tsurugi sword is the one that Susano used when he killed off Yamata no orochi (eight-forked-snake) (the sword is also called 'Ame no Habakiri' [a heavenly sword to cut a monster serpent]; "Haba" means "a monster serpent").

sen.j: 山幸彦と海幸彦の説話では、ホオリがホデリの釣り針を無くしてしまったため、自分の十拳剣を鋳潰して大量の針を作っている。
sen.e: According to the tale of Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko, Hoori lost Hoderi's fishing hook and melted down the totsuka no tsurugi in order to make a lot of hooks.

sen.j: 葦原中国平定の説話において、アメノワカヒコの葬儀に訪れたアジスキタカヒコネが、怒って十掬剣で喪屋を切り倒している。
sen.e: In the tale of suppressing Ashihara no nakatsukuni (another word for the country or the location of Japan), when Ajisukitakahikone attended a funeral of Ame no Wakahiko, he got angry and cut down the funeral hall with totsuka no tsurugi sword.

sen.e: Then Takemikazuchi and others stabbed totsuka no tsurugi sword backward in the sea in front of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region), and menaced sitting with his legs crossed on the point of the sword.
